questions.question: Regarding infanticide, feticide, and filicide in India, which of the following statement is incorrect? infanticide

options.A: Infanticide is punishable by death or imprisonment for life
options.B: Feticide is the killing of a fetus at any time prior to birth
options.C: The killing of a living child in the mother’s womb who has not yet breathed cannot be considered
options.D: Female feticide is the act of aborting a fetus because it is female

questions.explanation: cannot be considered infanticide Correct Answer: C) The killing of a living child in the mother’s womb who has not yet breathed cannot be considered infanticide Explanation: The causing of death of a living child in the mother’s womb may amount to culpable homicide, even though the child may not have breathed or been completely born (punishable under Sec. 299 IPC) . The various types of infanticides are listed in the table below: Term Definition Legal Aspects Infanticide Killing of an infant at any time from birth up to the age of 12 months Charged under Section (Option A) Punishable by death or imprisonment for life and fine Feticide (Option B) Killing of the fetus at any time prior to birth Causing the death of a quick unborn child amounts to culpable homicide Applies even if the child is killed in the womb and may not have breathed or been completely born (Culpable homicide- Sec.92 BNS) Punished with imprisonment up to 7 years and/or fine if with woman’s consent.(Sec.88 BNS) If without the woman’s consent up to 10 years with or without a fine. (Sec 89 BNS) Female Feticide (Option D) Act of aborting a fetus because it is female Covered under laws against feticide and sex determination Neonaticide Killing of a child within 24 hrs Filicide The deliberate act of killing a child by the parents Treated as murder under Section 103 BNS Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 320

questions.question: A stillborn fetus is discovered during a routine prenatal checkup. The fetus shows skin slippage on the face and back, soft and flaccid tissues, and a sweetish disagreeable smell, but no gas formation. The skull shows mild cranial compression but no overlapping of cranial sutures. Based on these findings, approximately how long ago did fetal death likely occur?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Between 36-48 hours ago Explanation: The baby shows signs of maceration such as skin slippage (occurs as early as 12 hours) & cranial compression (occurs after 36 hours) but no overlapping of cranial sutures (occurs >96 hours), which indicates fetal demise occurred after 36 hours but before 96 hours. Maceration: It is a process of aseptic autolysis of dead fetus inside the womb. This occurs when the dead child remains in the uterus for about 3–4 days surrounded with liquor amnii and with exclusion of air. Maceration changes in intrauterine death Time Since Death Maceration changes observed 12 hours Earliest sign: Skin slippage of face, back, or abdomen 24 hours Skin becomes brown or purplish in color > 36 hours Cranial compression becomes visible 72 hours (3 days) Desquamation over 75% of body surface > 96 hours (4 days) Overlapping of cranial sutures > 1 week Mouth is widely open Throughout process Fetus is soft and flaccid Sweetish disagreeable smell No gas formation Internal organs show autolytic decomposition (except lungs and uterus) Less than 12 hours ago (Option A) is incorrect because skin slippage is already present, which doesn't occur until at least 12 hours after death. Between 12-24 hours ago (Option B) is incorrect because while skin slippage is present, the cranial compression indicates more time has passed. More than 96 hours ago (Option D) is incorrect because while cranial compression is present, overlapping cranial sutures are absent, which would be expected after 96 hours. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 328

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with suspected intrauterine fetal death at 36 weeks gestation. Which of the following findings would be LEAST useful in confirming recent fetal demise?

options.B: Presence of skin slippage on the fetus's face and back
options.D: Absence of fetal heart sounds on electronic fetal monitoring

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Spalding's sign on ultrasonography. Explanation: Spalding's sign on ultrasonography is the least useful for confirming recent fetal demise . It typically appears about 7 days after fetal death , indicating prolonged intrauterine retention. By the time this sign is visible, the fetal death is no longer recent. Radiological Signs of Dead-born fetus Sign Imaging Modality Description Timeline Absence of Fetal Heart Motion (Option D) Ultrasound No detectable cardiac activity on real-time imaging Immediate indicator of fetal death- Absence of Fetal Movements Ultrasound No spontaneous or induced fetal movements during examination Immediate indicator of fetal death Robert's Sign (Option C) Ultrasound Gas bubbles in fetal heart chambers and great vessels May appear by 12 hours, but can be difficult to interpret Hyperflexion of Spine X-ray, Ultrasound Abnormal curvature of the fetal spine due to loss of muscle tone Variable, typically seen in later stages Spalding's Sign (Option A) Ultrasound Overlapping of fetal skull bones due to loss of brain tissue consistency Appears about 7 days after fetal death Loss of Rib Parallelism X-ray Ribs lose their normal parallel arrangement and overlap present Later sign, associated with collapse of thoracic cavity Deuel’s Halo Sign X-ray Indicates elevation of the subcutaneous fat layer from the underlying bone caused by edema Not reliable sign, as can be seen in both living and dead fetus Presence of skin slippage on the fetus's face and back (Option B): Skin slippage or maceration is a sign of fetal death that occurs after the fetus has been dead for several days, indicating the decomposition process.

questions.question: Match the following tests with their correct descriptions: 1. Wreden's test a. Compares the weight of lungs to body weight ratio before and after respiration 2. Ploucquet's test b. Checks for air bubbles in the stomach and intestines 3. Fodere's test (Static test) c. Examines the presence of air in the middle ear 4. Breslau's Second Life test d. Observes the weight change of lungs after respiration
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b Explanation: Tests for Stillborn vs Liveborn Test Name Description Key Points Wreden's test Examines the presence of air in the middle ear - Absence of gelatinous embryonic connective tissue - Presence of air in the middle ear after live birth Ploucquet's test Compares the weight of lungs to body weight ratio before and after respiration - Ratio before respiration: 1/70 of body weight - Ratio after respiration: 1/35 of body weight - Demonstrates establishment of respiration Fodere's test (Static test) Observes the weight change of lungs after respiration - Weight becomes approximately double after respiration due to increase in blood flow to lung beds after breathing - Not constant due to factors like edema, pneumonitis, or amniotic fluid inhalation Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page. 326, 327

questions.question: A forensic pathologist is examining the lungs of a newborn during an autopsy. The lungs appear mottled in color and occupy most of the thoracic cavity. However, when subjected to the hydrostatic test, portions of the lung tissue sink while others float. Microscopically, some areas show expanded alveoli lined with flat squamous cells, while other areas show closed alveoli lined with cuboidal cells. What is the most likely explanation for these conflicting findings?

options.A: The infant was stillborn, and the floating lung portions are due to putrefaction
options.B: The infant was live-born but suffered from severe respiratory distress syndrome
options.C: The infant was live-born and partially breathed before death
options.D: The findings are inconclusive and could be due to artificial respiration attempts

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) The infant was live-born and partially breathed before death Explanation: The findings support that the infant was live-born and partially respired before death , based on: Mottled appearance of lungs and partial thoracic cavity expansion , indicating some aeration. Mixed hydrostatic test results- some lung parts floated while others sank. Microscopy showed: Expanded alveoli lined with flat squamous cells (indicating respiration). Closed alveoli lined with cuboidal/columnar cells (indicating unrespired areas). Comparison: Respired vs. Unrespired Lung Feature Unrespired Lung (Stillborn) Respired Lung (Live-born) Color Bluish red Mottled Volume Small Large, covers heart Thoracic cavity Not full Fully occupied Pleura Loose, wrinkled Taut, stretched Margins Sharp Rounded Surface Smooth Uneven Consistency Dense, firm, non-crepitant (liver-like) Soft, spongy, elastic, crepitant Ploucquet's test 1:70 1:35 Fodere's static test 30–40 g 60–70 g Diaphragm level 4th–5th rib 6th–7th rib Blood oozing Little, frothless Abundant, frothy Hydrostatic test Whole and parts sink in water Floats in water Alveoli Not expanded Expanded Microscopy Closed sacs with cuboidal/columnar lining Dilated sacs with flat squamous lining and vascularity The infant was stillborn, and the floating lung portions are due to putrefaction (Option A): Incorrect because although putrefaction can produce gas leading to lung flotation, microscopy revealed expanded alveoli with flattened squamous cells , indicating actual respiration, not decomposition. The infant was live-born but suffered from severe respiratory distress syndrome (Option B): Incorrect because RDS usually leads to generalized alveolar collapse , not the mixed pattern of both inflated and collapsed alveoli observed here. The findings are inconclusive and could be due to artificial respiration attempt (Option D): Incorrect because artificial respiration typically causes more uniform aeration of the lungs . The patchy aeration pattern and histological evidence of both respired and unrespired areas support partial natural breathing , not artificial intervention alone. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 326

questions.question: A forensic examiner is evaluating two fetuses found under different circumstances. The examiner performs Breslau’s First Life Test on Baby A and Breslau’s Second Life Test on Baby B. The findings are as follows: For Baby A, after performing the hydrostatic test, the lungs sink when compressed and placed back in water. For Baby B, air bubbles are observed escaping from the stomach and intestines after an incision is made underwater. What do these findings suggest about the live birth status of both babies?

options.A: Baby A was stillborn, while Baby B was born alive and breathed.
options.B: Baby A was born alive and breathed, while Baby B was stillborn.
options.C: Both Baby A and Baby B were born alive and breathed.
options.D: Both tests are inconclusive due to potential contamination.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Baby A was stillborn, while Baby B was born alive and breathed. Explanation: The hydrostatic test showed that Baby A's lungs sank, indicating they were unrespired and thus confirming stillbirth. In contrast, Baby B showed air bubbles escaping from the stomach and intestines, suggesting that respiration occurred, confirming live birth. Hydrostatic Test/ Raygat Test/ Breslau’s First Life Test Principle: Based on the specific gravity of the lungs; before respiration, it is 1040–1050, and after respiration, it is 940-950, allowing the lungs to float. Procedure: Dissect out the fetal lungs and tie them at the hilar region. Place both lungs in a trough of water and observe. Inference: If they sink: Unrespired lung. If they float: Remove from water, cut into small pieces, and compress between sponges, then re-test in water. If they sink: Unrespired lung. If they float: Respired lung. Floating indicates residual air in the lungs from breathing after birth. False positive: Caused by putrefying gasses or artificial inflation. False negative: Caused by conditions like atelectasis, edema, feeble respiration, pneumonia, or congenital syphilis. A hydrostatic test is not necessary if: The fetus shows congenital anomalies (e.g., anencephaly) The fetus is macerated or mummified The umbilical cord has separated and scarred The stomach contains milk Bruises on the lungs indicate artificial respiration efforts The fetus is born before 180 days of gestation Breslau’s Second Life Test Steps: Remove the stomach and intestines, tying double ligatures at each end. Submerge them in water. Make an incision between the ligatures. Interpretation: If air bubbles emerge, it indicates that respiration has occurred, confirming live birth. The presence of milk in the stomach also serves as positive evidence of live birth. Baby A was born alive and breathed, while Baby B was stillborn. (Option B): If Baby A had been born alive, the lungs would have floated during the hydrostatic test, indicating respiration. The sinking of the lungs confirms stillbirth. Baby B's air bubbles indicate that it was born alive. Both Baby A and Baby B were born alive and breathed. (Option C): Baby A's lungs did not float, which indicates it was stillborn. Therefore, it cannot be concluded that both babies were born alive. Both tests are inconclusive due to potential contamination. (Option D): Baby A’s sinking lungs definitively indicate stillbirth and Baby B's air bubbles confirm live birth, making the tests conclusive.

questions.question: A newborn is examined shortly after delivery. The physician observes a localized swelling on the baby’s head that appears several hours after birth. The swelling is confined to one side of the skull, is firm to the touch, and does not cross the suture lines. What is the most likely diagnosis for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cephalohematoma Explanation: Cephalohematoma refers to a localized collection of blood between the skull and the periosteum, often appearing several hours after birth. It is typically unilateral, firm to the touch, and confined by the suture lines, matching the characteristics noted in the scenario. Feature Cephalohematoma Caput Succedaneum (Option A) Definition Blood collection between the periosteum and skull due to a ruptured emissary vein, often from trauma (e.g., forceps delivery). Swelling from fluid accumulation between scalp layers, typically from prolonged pressure (e.g., during labor). Situation Generally unilateral, commonly over the parietal bone. Can be bilateral, covering a broader area of the scalp. Impulse on Crying ( Seen in hydrocephalus) No impulse seen. No impulse seen. Limitation by Suture Line Confined by sutures. No restriction by sutures. Underlying Pathology May involve a skull fracture. Non-pathological; usually harmless. Occurrence Does not appear at birth, and usually develops later. Present at birth. Development and Disappearance Appears 12–24 hours after birth, and resolves in 6–8 weeks. Maybe followed by jaundice. Disappears on its own within 24 hours. Maybe followed by jaundice. Medico-Legal Importance Can assist in determining how long the infant survived post-birth based on regression. Provides clear evidence of in-utero life, though, in prolonged labor, fetal death may occur before birth. Hydrocephalus (Option C) involves fluid accumulation in the brain ventricles, leading to overall head enlargement rather than localized swelling. Intracranial hemorrhage (Option D) involves bleeding within the skull, typically presenting with more severe symptoms and not as a confined scalp swelling.

questions.question: A 3-month-old infant is found unresponsive in their crib by a caregiver early in the morning. The infant had been healthy and fed well the previous evening. The caregiver reports the baby typically sleeps on their stomach. An autopsy is performed, revealing no conclusive cause of death. Which of the following statements is most accurate based on the scenario?

options.A: Sleeping on the stomach significantly reduces the risk of death.
options.B: The autopsy typically reveals specific pathological findings.
options.C: Low birth weight or premature infants have an increased risk of sudden death.
options.D: Maternal smoking has no post-natal association with infant mortality.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Low birth weight or premature infants have an increased risk of sudden death. various factors, including underdeveloped respiratory systems and increased vulnerability. Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) The sudden and unexpected death of a seemingly healthy infant, with no explanation after a complete autopsy. It is an autopsy diagnosis, not a clinical one. Features Incidence: 0.2–0.4% of all live births. Most vulnerable between 2 weeks and 2 years, peaking at 2–4 months. The higher death rate in males (M: F ratio 3:2). More prevalent in low and middle-class families with poor housing conditions, larger families, and a lack of health awareness. Typically found dead in the early morning or after the first feed. Increased risk among twins, particularly those who are premature or of low birth weight. Increased risk linked to maternal smoking (pre- or postnatal) and drug abuse. (Option D) Cause Prolonged sleep apnea, leads to hypoxia. Respiratory infections cause viremia and sleep depression in the respiratory center. Nasal edema and mucus narrowing airways. Possible hypersensitivity to cow’s milk causing laryngeal spasm. Accidental suffocation from bedclothes or overlying by a caregiver. The increased risk is associated with prone or side sleeping positions. (Option A) Miscellaneous causes include metabolic deficiencies and environmental factors. Postmortem Findings Generally negative or non-specific pathological findings . (Option B) The trachea may contain milky vomit, sometimes blood-stained. Multiple petechial hemorrhages on the heart, lungs, and thymus (agonal). Common pulmonary edema. Possible milk or blood-stained froth at the mouth or bedding, with hands clenched around bedclothes. Medico-Legal Aspects SIDS is considered a natural death; however, parents may be wrongfully suspected of criminal involvement or negligence. Some infanticide cases may be misrepresented as SIDS. Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 346 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 333, 334

questions.question: A 6-year-old child is frequently admitted with gastrointestinal distress, including vomiting and abdominal pain. The mother provides elaborate details about the symptoms and insists on multiple tests despite negative results. Symptoms appear only when the mother is present, and the child seems healthy when separated. What is the most likely diagnosis for the child’s condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy Explanation: Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy is a form of abuse where a caregiver fabricates or induces symptoms in a child for attention. Children may present with vague complaints like vomiting, diarrhea, fever, or seizures, often inflicted intentionally by the parent (e.g., using anticoagulants, suffocation, ipecac syrup). The caregiver derives personal benefit, such as attention or sympathy, at the child's expense. Diagnosis The illness does not conform to expected patterns or courses. Symptoms are not supported by lab or imaging results. Injuries or wounds may fail to heal properly. The child’s condition may worsen in the presence of the caregiver and improve when separated. Positive drug tests for substances not prescribed to the child. The child may have been admitted to various hospitals and seen by numerous physicians. Gastroenteritis (Option A): This condition typically presents with clear, objective symptoms such as diarrhea and fever, which would be consistent across different caregivers. The lack of objective findings in this scenario makes gastroenteritis unlikely. Functional Abdominal Pain (Option C): While this condition can cause recurrent abdominal pain, it usually lacks the distinct pattern of worsening in the presence of a caregiver. The clear connection to the mother’s presence makes this diagnosis less likely. Anxiety Disorder (Option D): Although anxiety can manifest in physical symptoms, it wouldn't typically cause the specific pattern observed here, where the child’s symptoms are linked to the presence of the mother. This option does not explain the mother's insistence on testing and the lack of objective findings. Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 346 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 334

questions.question: A 2-year-old girl presents with persistent crying, refusal to eat, and multiple bruises. The parents report frequent falls. On exam, there are bruises on the abdomen and back, a healing burn on the thigh, and rib tenderness. X-ray done is shown below. The parents give vague explanations and claim the child "bruises easily." A CT scan reveals subdural hematoma without a clear trauma history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
